recommended_next_actions: Restrict monitoring/debug endpoints to trusted admin or monitoring networks only; add authentication/authorization controls where supported.
Reduce attack surface by closing unused listeners and rebinding critical services from wildcard interfaces to least-privilege network zones.
Limit PostgreSQL exposure to required application hosts and enforce strong auth/TLS policies for database connectivity.
Harden Redis: require authentication/ACLs, bind to localhost or private interfaces, and block untrusted network access at the firewall.
Collect SOC 2 control-operation evidence not assessable by scanning (JML/access reviews, change approvals, incident response drills, and policy governance records).
After remediation, rerun the readiness assessment and compare deltas in findings severity, exposed services, and evidence artifacts.

actions.reasoning: SOC 2 evidence goal: demonstrate ongoing vulnerability assessment and exposure management by validating whether previously identified sensitive areas (e.g., /config/, /README.md, /robots.txt) extend to additional undiscovered unauthenticated endpoints on the primary app. A focused content discovery run on the main web app can uncover admin panels, backups, or configuration artifacts that materially change risk posture and remediation scope.
actions.hypothesis: The application on :3001 exposes additional hidden or unlinked sensitive paths (admin, backups, config leaks) beyond those already found, increasing likelihood of unauthorized access or data disclosure.
actions.expected_evidence: HTTP 200/30x responses for high-risk paths (e.g., /admin, /backup, /.env, /config.php, /phpinfo.php, /db.sql, /api/docs) with response sizes/titles indicating sensitive content or privileged functionality.

plans.notes: Only one action proposed (remaining_actions=1). Note: gobuster and nuclei/httpx/whatweb for this target/profile were already run; ffuf provides complementary fuzzing-based discovery not excluded for :3001 in constraints.

llm_thinking_events.message: Formulating audit expansion plan with tool-calling

selected=ffuf p10 @http://localhost:3001 | rationale=SOC 2 evidence goal: demonstrate ongoing vulnerability assessment and exposure management by validating whether previously identified sensitive areas (e.g., /config/, /README.md... | hypothesis=The application on :3001 exposes additional hidden or unlinked sensitive paths (admin, backups, config leaks) beyond those already found, increasing likelihood of unauthorized a... | expect=HTTP 200/30x responses for high-risk paths (e.g., /admin, /backup, /.env, /config.php, /phpinfo.php, /db.sql, /api/docs) with response sizes/titles indicating sensitive content...

summary.summary: The localhost environment exposes multiple unauthenticated administrative/metrics endpoints and Supabase secrets, including a service role key, creating immediate risk of full database access, user enumeration, and sensitive configuration disclosure. Several data services (Postgres/Redis/metrics) are reachable and some listen on wildcard interfaces, increasing the attack surface.

findings.title: Supabase service role key exposed (credential/secrets leakage)
findings.evidence: Supabase audit detected service role JWT in content: key=eyJhbG….sig, source=http://localhost:4001
findings.recommendation: Rotate the service role key immediately, remove it from any client-accessible responses/assets, and restrict usage to trusted server-side components only.

findings.title: Prometheus accessible without authentication (config exposure)
findings.evidence: Prometheus config endpoint reachable: http://localhost:9090/api/v1/status/config (HTTP 200); nuclei also flagged unauth Prometheus at the same endpoint
findings.recommendation: Require authentication/authorization for Prometheus UI and APIs, and restrict access via firewall/allowlist (bind to localhost or internal network only).

findings.title: Supabase REST API accessible without authentication / potential missing RLS
findings.evidence: REST endpoint reachable without auth: http://localhost:4001/rest/v1/ (HTTP 200); tool notes 'RLS may be disabled'
findings.recommendation: Enable and verify Row Level Security (RLS) on all tables, ensure policies are least-privilege, and require appropriate API keys/JWT auth for data access.

findings.title: Unauthenticated Supabase RPC allows user enumeration
findings.recommendation: Restrict RPC execution to authenticated roles, add explicit role checks within functions, and ensure underlying tables/views are protected by RLS/policies.

findings.title: Unauthenticated metrics endpoints exposed
findings.evidence: Metrics accessible: http://localhost:8080/metrics (HTTP 200) and http://localhost:9090/metrics (HTTP 200); nuclei detected Prometheus metrics endpoints
findings.recommendation: Protect metrics with authentication and/or network segmentation; avoid exposing metrics publicly as they can leak internal topology, versions, and operational data.

findings.title: Redis reachable without authentication
findings.evidence: readiness_probe: redis-cli PING returned PONG for localhost:6379
findings.recommendation: Enable Redis AUTH/ACLs, bind to localhost/internal interfaces, and enforce firewall rules to prevent untrusted network access.

findings.title: Sensitive services listening on wildcard interfaces (increased exposure)
findings.evidence: ss -lnt shows wildcard listeners on ports: 5432, 6379, 8080, 9090, 9100
findings.recommendation: Bind services to localhost/internal interfaces where possible and enforce host/network firewall policies to limit access to trusted sources only.

findings.title: Directory listing / sensitive configuration path detected
findings.evidence: nuclei: Sensitive Configuration Files Listing - Detect at http://localhost:3001/config/
findings.recommendation: Disable directory listing, remove sensitive files from web roots, and restrict access to configuration endpoints/paths.

findings.title: Go pprof debug endpoint exposed
findings.recommendation: Disable pprof in production or restrict it to localhost/admin networks with authentication to prevent information leakage and potential DoS vectors.

findings.title: Supabase anon key exposed in client content
findings.evidence: Supabase audit detected anon JWT in content: key=eyJhbG….sig, source=http://localhost:4001
findings.recommendation: Treat anon keys as public but ensure RLS and policies prevent data exposure; rotate if mistakenly granted elevated privileges and minimize scope/permissions.
